posts.content: We‚Äôre thrilled to announce the 15th annual VIZBI meeting on ‚ÄòVisualizing Biological Data‚Äô (https://vizbi.org). Each year, we invite 21 world-leading experts in data visualization and the life sciences. Every meeting has been amazing, and this year is shaping up to be our best ever! We're at a fantastic location at the University of Cambridge, UK. Join us in-person or online!

++++
Featured Researcher:, Graduated in
in December 2024

‚ÄúAs an undergraduate researcher at UMass Boston, I have developed AmpliVision, a software for automated readout of a Ampli tests which can be trained to recognize the
pattern of different diseases using few mobile phone pictures.

Ampli is a reconfigurable version of lateral flow assays (LFAs), or rapid tests, where test components are broken down into modular, LEGO-like blocks that can be snapped together in different configurations, allowing for flexible and adaptable
.

Automated Ampli tests have the potential to make a significant public health impact on infectious disease control as widely distributed user-centric diagnostics. I aim to make these tests more accessible for widespread use, particularly for visually impaired users, who may be unable to perceive color differences.

I am particularly passionate about creating resourceful, accessible solutions that maximize widespread technology‚Äîsuch as using a smartphone for diagnostics instead of requiring new physical devices. This approach ensures that innovations in disease detection can reach more people without adding unnecessary costs or barriers.

My work would not have been possible without the guidance of my advisors, Professors Kimberly Hamad-Schifferli and Daniel Haehn, as well as PhD candidate Josselyn Mata, whose insights have been instrumental in shaping my research. It would have also not been possible without UMass Boston's excellent undergraduate research opportunities, including U54 (UMass Boston‚ÄìDana-Farber/Harvard Cancer Center partnership), the IDS Fellowship, and BSSF (Beacon Student Success Fellowship), which provide invaluable support for student-led research.

Additionally, it was an honor to present my research at the
Conference in Pittsburgh, where I had the incredible opportunity to meet and share my work with a broader scientific community and was humbled to receive an award for my presentation.‚Äù

In the photo: Matheus,,, and(left to right), at the Annual Research Symposium at
presenting early developments of AmpliVision as of Summer 2024.

VISUALIZING BIOLOGICAL DATA. Join us 8-11 April online or in-person at the University of Cambridge for VIZBI 2025, the 15th international meeting on Visualising Biological Data. Pre-register now at.

DATAVIS ADVANCES. Highlights include keynotes on cutting-edge DataVis methods from Marc Streit ('Explainable AI') and Tobias Isenberg ('In¬≠ter¬≠ac¬≠tive data ex¬≠plo¬≠ra¬≠tion in 2D & 3D'), and a masterclass from Drew Berry ('Visual storytelling')..

LIFE SCIENCE BREAKTHROUGHS. The VIZBI workshop features inspiring talks from 21 world-leading researchers on visualizations transforming how life scientists understand data..

DATAVIS MASTERCLASS. The meeting also features a one-day intensive DataVis training event from world-leading practitioners..

WHY ATTEND? You can present your work and engage with a unique community of leading practitioners, including scientists, data visualization specialists, medical illustrators, graphic designers, and industry leaders..

SECURE YOUR SPOT. You can ensure your Early Bird discount, and your slot as poster presenter by pre-registering at#pre-register.

What a day! 5 years ago I was hooded by my doctoral advisor Hanspeter Pfisterat theand now I hooded my first PhD Dr.at. Will never forget both days :)

I feel very blessed to receive two awards this semester - here the announcement from CS Department Chair:

Daniel got this year's CSM Excellence in Undergraduate Education Award . Since his arrival at UMB, Daniel has energized the department and made a huge difference to our students through his teaching and event organizing. Congratulations as well!

Being an award collector, Daniel also just received a Center for Innovative Teaching (CIT) Award for Inclusive Pedagogies at UMass Boston. The CIT's reasoning for this award describes Daniel's achievements very well:

"Your dedication to fostering inclusivity and diversity within the classroom environment, along with your innovative approaches to decolonizing pedagogies and universal teaching designs, has truly set you apart. Your commitment to creating welcoming and supportive atmospheres for students from all backgrounds, incorporating diverse voices and perspectives into the curriculum, and actively engaging students in the learning process has not gone unnoticed. Your efforts have not only enhanced accessibility and engagement for all students but have also contributed to positive student feedback, learning outcomes, and retention rates. Also, your leadership qualities in advocating for inclusive teaching practices and fostering collaboration among faculty, staff, and students have been commendable."

Thank you so much!! Here is my speech:

I might be biased ü§£ but aren't those the most beautiful posters ever!! 

So proud of Edward Gaibor Shruti Varade sang hyuk kim Jenna Kim- thank you for the always excellent work!!

I'm very excited to host Professor Daniel Haehn at my deep learning lecture series next Monday, 03/04! Since I'll be out of town, I'll give my intro and advert here:

is the leader of theLab here at. This group pursues the exciting connection between computational methods and neurobiology. Last year alone, his group published 7 papers on this intersection, with important and exciting work in breast cancer (Mammogram outlier detection) and Epilepsy (localizing the epileptogenic zone for surgeons). His work is very inspiring, as he and his group apply modern deep learning techniques to real-world medical problems of utmost importance. I think it's awesome to see this connection between fundamental research and user-focused applications.

Details on Professor Haehn's Code-Oriented Lecture:

*Edge Computing: Cats versus Dogs in the browser*

Abstract: The cats versus dogs image classification is a classic example of deep learning. We will explore it first using Colab and then move it to the edge: running in the web-browser using tensorflow.js.


Join in to learn more about writing code for deep learning projects! So far, we've had a great time discussing datasets, training, transfer learning, MLPs, CNNs, and ResNets. When we resume after spring break (18 March), we'll continue discussing RNNs and LSTMs before Attention and Transformers the following week. We'll spend the remainder of the semester discussing the exciting realm of Reinforcement Learning.

As usual, the lecture will be in ISC 1400, Monday 4 March, 11a-1p. Hope to have you there!

Buzzfeed recently published a now deleted article on what AI thinks Barbies would look like from different countries around the world.

The results contained extreme forms of representational bias - including colourist and racist depictions, which is something that AI image generators are often prone to doing.

With AI image generators like MidJourney, Stable Diffusion, and Dall-E gaining huge popularity, it‚Äôs important that we are vigilant about the forms of bias that these technologies can fuel.

We have the recent Llama2 ready to go here at UMass Boston for your fine-tuning needs!

PhD Student(see how focused he is in the picture :)) set up a python-based wrapper for easy access to chat features leveraging 70 billion parameters using 8 parallel A100 GPUs.

Single-click annotation of carotid plaque in CTA scans - all open source!

Exciting work by UMass Boston PhD student Jenna Kim in collaboration withfrom the!

This French national women's soccer team advertisement has been making waves since being released recently, and for good reason! It showcases a perfect example of how generative AI technology can be used for beneficial changes by highlighting gender stereotypes ingrained in our modern society.

The developments in AI are quickly pushing our society into a new world, and it's important to highlight positive examples like this. We must continue to push for progress by looking for biases, callout out stereotypes, and ensuring inclusivity and diversity within our personal lives, work, and datasets.

The real danger in the latest AI models is not them taking over the world, it's in them reinforcing the one we already live in.

Today, I woke up to the disheartening news of Kevin Mitnick's passing. Just months ago, I added the 
hashtag
#FREEKEVIN banner to my website, a tribute to the man whose legendary social engineering skills captivated me in my teenage years.

Kevin's influence extended far beyond just my life - his remarkable skillset and charisma made him an iconic figure in the global
community. The yellow
stickers were a symbol of his standing, a popularity that was undeniable and well-deserved despite all controversies.

Today, we mourn a legend. Rest in Peace,. Your legacy will continue to inspire.


Here is the code for the
JS console print:

```console.log('%cFREE KEVIN', 'font-weight:1000;color: black; background: orange; padding:10px; font-size: 120px');```

It's so easy, even I can do it. :) A co-worker just published a wonderfully clear tutorial on how to convert a sequence of C++ ITK filters into a web assembly module that can be called from python, RUST, javascript, R, and many other languages. With support for multi-threading and complex data structures, web assembly is going to absolutely change how scientific computing is delivered for desktop, web, client-server apps, and whatever comes next...

Very honored and excited to be part of this team and this very important mission!

A device called Dotplot that helps women self-check at home to detect breast cancer has won the prestigious UK James Dyson Award.

As usual, medical professionals have welcomed the invention but warn it is no substitute for going to the doctor.

"Users build a personalised map of their torso by inputting their breast size and shape and pressing the handheld device over their chest.

Once a month, soundwaves are used to record tissue composition - and if there are any suspicious changes or abnormalities, users are advised to see a healthcare professional."

A typical
innovation. We bring something from the point-of-care to patients' homes to engage them more in their care.
